A quick #WorldEmojiDay exploration

6 minute(s) read

Letâ€™s celebrate #WorldEmojiDay with a quick exploration of my own twitter account.

The ðŸ“¦

Weâ€™ll need:

From Github

  • {emo}
remote::install_github("hadley/emo")

From CRAN

  • {dplyr}
  • {tidyr}
  • {rtweet}
  • {tidytext}

Note: This page has been created at:

Sys.time()

## [1] "2018-07-17 17:22:29 CEST"

The ðŸ”

Letâ€™s get my last 3200 tweets:

library(emo)
library(rtweet)
library(dplyr)

  "_ColinFay",
  n = 3200
)

Here is what the text column looks like:

res %>% 
  pull(text) %>%
  .[1:5]

## [1] "@GoldbergData It adds a little label at the top left with the text you provide. \nCan be useful if you want to add some legends in a markdown / shiny app, for example"
## [2] "#RStats \nCool new feature in ggplot2 v3 â€” tagging plots : https://t.co/jFUqX2Tj5T"                                                                                    
## [3] "#RStats â€” A perfect introduction to \U0001f5fa with the {sf} \U0001f4e6 &amp; Co by @statnmap : \nhttps://t.co/IrmcSBDMDy https://t.co/m3TyUjrxYF"                     
## [4] "@vsbuffalo Amen to that"                                                                                                                                               
## [5] "#RStats â€” \U0001f680 Setting up RStudio Server, Shiny Server and PostgreSQL :\nhttps://t.co/J1Y7edNAj0"

As you can see, the emojis are not printed in the console, but converted to weird characters like \U0001f4e6 and such. These are unicode characters: translations of the emojis into a language your machine can understand. I wonâ€™t go deeper into this, here are two resources you can read if you want to know more about encoding:

  • The Absolute Minimum Every Software Developer Absolutely, Positively Must Know About Unicode and Character Sets (No Excuses!)

  • What emojis tell us about encoding

The ðŸ“Š

Letâ€™s use the {emo} package to extract the emojis from the text. Inspired by {stringr}, this package has a ji_extract_all function that is designed to extract all the emojis from a character vector. Weâ€™ll use it on out text column, then extract the date and emo column. We then pass the result to tidyr::unnest in order to remove the empty emo rows (i.e, the tweets without an emoji).

library(tidyr)
emos <- res %>%
  mutate(
    emo = ji_extract_all(text)
  ) %>%
  select(created_at,emo) %>%
  unnest(emo)

emos

## # A tibble: 887 x 2
##    created_at          emo  
##    <dttm>              <chr>
##  1 2018-07-17 10:00:47 ðŸ“¦   
##  2 2018-07-17 08:35:05 ðŸš€   
##  3 2018-07-16 18:47:25 ðŸ˜®   
##  4 2018-07-16 14:51:30 ðŸ˜

##  7 2018-07-16 13:27:00 ðŸ˜ˆ

##  9 2018-07-16 13:27:00 ðŸ’€

So apparently, I use a lot of ðŸ¤”. But also talk about ðŸ“¦, which sounds more appropriate :)

As you can see, {tibble} converts elements to emojis when printing. When using a data.frame, you have a simple unicode translation:

emos %>%
  as.data.frame() %>%
  head()

##            created_at        emo
## 1 2018-07-17 10:00:47 \U0001f4e6
## 2 2018-07-17 08:35:05 \U0001f680
## 3 2018-07-16 18:47:25 \U0001f62e
## 4 2018-07-16 14:51:30 \U0001f601
## 5 2018-07-16 14:51:16 \U0001f631
## 6 2018-07-16 13:28:08 \U0001f352

The ðŸ·

Letâ€™s flag all the emojis with their names:

emos %>%
  left_join(
    data.frame(
      emo = ji_name, 
      name = names(ji_name)
    )
  ) %>% 
  count(emo, name, sort = TRUE)

## Joining, by = "emo"

## Warning: Column `emo` joining character vector and factor, coercing into
## character vector

The ðŸ” 

And finally, letâ€™s see what are the most associated words with the emojis we just saw:

library(tidytext)
emos_with_id <- res %>%
  mutate(
    emo = ji_extract_all(text)
  ) %>% 
  select(status_id, text, emo) %>%
  tidyr::unnest(emo)

emos_with_id %>%
  unnest_tokens(word,text) %>%
  anti_join(stop_words) %>%
  anti_join(proustr::stop_words) %>%
  anti_join(
    data.frame(
      word = c("https", "t.co", "https", "gt")
    )
  ) %>% 
  count(emo, word, sort = TRUE)

## Joining, by = "word"
## Joining, by = "word"
## Joining, by = "word"

## Warning: Column `word` joining character vector and factor, coercing into
## character vector

## # A tibble: 5,660 x 3
##    emo   word          n
##    <chr> <chr>     <int>
##  1 ðŸ“¦    rstats       37
##  2 ðŸŽ‰    rstats       27
##  3 ðŸ’»    macbook      26
##  4 ðŸ“¦    package      20
##  5 ðŸ‘    trans        18
##  6 â˜•    pm           15
##  7 ðŸ’»    pro          15
##  8 ðŸ’»    marche       10
##  9 ðŸ¤”    ma_salmon    10
## 10 ðŸ˜±    ma_salmon    10
## # ... with 5,650 more rows

And what are the most used emojis with â€œrstatsâ€?

emos_with_id %>%
  unnest_tokens(word, text) %>%
  anti_join(stop_words) %>%
  anti_join(proustr::stop_words) %>%
  anti_join(
    data.frame(
      word = c("https", "t.co", "https", "gt")
    )
  ) %>%
  count(emo, word, sort = TRUE) %>%
  filter(
    word == "rstats"
  )

## Joining, by = "word"
## Joining, by = "word"
## Joining, by = "word"

## Warning: Column `word` joining character vector and factor, coercing into
## character vector

## # A tibble: 81 x 3
##    emo   word       n
##    <chr> <chr>  <int>
##  1 ðŸ“¦    rstats    37
##  2 ðŸŽ‰    rstats    27
##  3 ðŸ˜¬    rstats     5
##  4 ðŸŒŸ    rstats     4

##  7 âœï¸    rstats     3
##  8 ðŸ’Ž    rstats     3
##  9 ðŸ™Œ    rstats     3
## 10 âš¡    rstats     2

Other cool functions

I recently discovered the ji_glue() function which allows you to insert an emoji easily into a character vector :

ji_glue("I love to code :package:")

## I love to code ðŸ“¦

ji_glue("Sometimes they make me :scream:")

## Sometimes they make me ðŸ˜±

ji_glue("Sometimes they make me :cry:")

## Sometimes they make me ðŸ˜¢

ji_glue("Sometimes they make me :fear:")

## Sometimes they make me ðŸ˜¨

ji_glue("But in the end I'm always :tada:")

## But in the end I'm always ðŸŽ‰

The ji() function can also be used inside your markdown, so you can write:

â€œI hate backtick r emo::ji(â€bugâ€œ) backtickâ€, and it will come as: â€œI hate ðŸ›â€.

(of course, replace backtick by actuwith backticks :) ).

Thatâ€™s all folks ðŸŽ¬

Thatâ€™s all for today! Now have a nice emoji day ðŸŽ‰
